card.name: Design Stories
card.desc:
# FORMAT

Goal(s)
Job Stories (which become sub-tasks)
Out of Scope
Deliverables
[Other Design Requirements]


# EXAMPLE 1

**Goal(s)**

Continue research into needs for portal and wireframe screens.

Start with use cases for:

- Login
- Password Recovery
- Employee Activation Flow
- Customer Add/Edit
- Employee Profile
- Employee Add/Edit
- 1-2 others based on scope from PM?

**Job Stories**

1. [Employee] When I want to [add a customer / run a report / make an update / etc.], I want to log into the system quickly, so that I can perform the task at hand.
1. [Employee] When I can’t remember my password, I want to reset it easily, so I can get back into the system to perform my job.
1. [Employee] When I’ve been invited to sign up for an account, I want to be able to provide my information, so that I can start using the system to perform my job (e.g., start supporting customers).
1. [Employee] When I want to update [my password / name / etc.], I want to be able to easily update my profile, so that my record is up to date.
1. [Support] When I have a new Customer on the phone, I want to add them to the system quickly, so that we can start the provisioning process (i.e., get them energy, or the service) as soon as possible (to recognize revenue).
1. [Support] When I want to update an existing Customer’s information (e.g., they moved), I want to update their record easily, so that their information will be up to date (i.e., they’re properly billed / they get future bills in the mail / etc.).
1. [Admin] When I have a new Employee who needs access to the system, I want to be able to add them easily, so I can get them using the system right away.
1. [Admin] When I want to update an existing Employee’s information (e.g., role), I want to update their record quickly, so I can support them in doing their their job.

**Out of Scope**

Mobile screen sizes. To be researched.

**Deliverables**

Wireframes from Sketch, prototyped in InVision.

Tasks and corresponding usability test feedback from at least 5 testers.



# Example 2

**Goal**

We’ll need branded emails in order to communicate to customers from the system, including sending bills to customers.

**Job Stories**

1. [Customer] When a bill has been created, I want to receive it in my inbox, so that I can review it.
1. [Customer] When an account is created for me, I want to receive a welcome email, so that I know that I what future emails to expect.
1. [Customer] When I make a purchase (via a CSR), I want to receive an email letting me know what I purchased, so that I can feel confident the changes I wanted will be made, and so that I know its impact on my next bill.

**Design Requirements**

Emails must be brand-able (via logo and colors only).

Emails must be responsive.

**Deliverables**

Responsive HTML and images for above emails.

Source delivered to dev to GTBilling repo (if possible).

Images deployed to S3 bucket (for Billing project), if setup in time; otherwise some other public URL for testing.

listing.overview: Add custom fields like text, numbers, checkboxes, dates, and dropdown lists to your cards.
listing.description:
Custom data fields for Trello cards.

Ever want to add a dropdown menu, checkbox, or additional date fields to Trello cards? The Custom Fields Power-Up let’s you do all that and more, bringing process and formality to your workflow to meet your team’s unique needs. Whether it’s number fields to track feature requests, additional date fields for start and end dates of marketing campaigns, dropdown menus of SKUs to manage orders from customers, and more, Custom Fields has you covered. Plus, field data is surfaced to the front of Trello cards for information in a glance.

- Custom fields for text, numbers, checkboxes, dates, and dropdown lists.
- Display field data as card badges on the front of cards.
- Field names support emoji for extra visual appeal.
- Custom Fields are supported on mobile devices.
- Export Custom Fields data in JSON and CSV board exports. *Note: CSV exports are only available on Business Class and Enterprise teams.*

![screenshot](https://card-fields.trello.services/images/custom-fields-1.jpg)
![screenshot](https://card-fields.trello.services/images/custom-fields-2.jpg)
![screenshot](https://card-fields.trello.services/images/custom-fields-3.jpg)

card.name: Interview Stakeholders
card.desc:
Stakeholder Interviews

- [Article - UX Process Starts at Stakeholder Interviews](https://uxdesign.cc/ux-process-starts-at-stakeholder-interviews-not-user-interviews-4b464368d7d3)
  - What is the requested feature/product/enhancement?
  - What is the expected timeline in stakeholders’ minds? Are they aligned?
  - Who are the intended users for the feature/product?
  - What are the constraints/worries that exist regarding this effort?

Questions:

- Who’s involved?
- Who needs to stay updated and how?
  - Who do I need to bring into design reviews and other activities?
- RACI: Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed

Issue Tracker

Spreadsheet easier to use than JIRA (and without the overhead), to capture suggestions, bugs (show that stakeholders are being listened to), do triage, and to look for patterns.

🛠 **Tools**: Stakeholder Interviews, RACI, Issue Tracker, MoSCoW

[Issue Tracker example + columns]

card.name: Jobs To Be Done
card.desc:
(Ulwick)

→ Survey for existing features
→ Job Map

(Summarize the Following)


# My JTBD Approach

## Identify what job the customer is trying to get done.
 
- Expressed as a Job Story:
    - When…(situation) I want… (motivation) so that… (expected outcome).
- We think about the job from the customer’s perspective, not the company’s. 
- We think big; to encompass the entire job, not just a piece of it.
- Functional jobs define the tasks people seek to accomplish, personal jobs explain the way people want to feel in a given circumstance, and social jobs clarify how people want to be perceived by others.

🛠 Tooling: I use an empty Trello board. Starting from the left: 

- "TO FILE" - For all the ideas that arise during this process, without worrying where to put them right away.
- “JTBD" - For the job itself. I also attach a sketch of the flow here.
- Following that, each column represents each process step (“Discovery”, “Sign Up”, etc.). Use the Universal Job Map (below) if needed to determine ideas for each column.

## For each Job...

a.) Determine stages (process steps) for the job. Can be based on the Universal Job Map (if helpful as a starting point):
 
- Define. Customers determine their goals and plan resources. Simplify planning.
- Locate. Customers gather items and information necessary to do the job.
- Prepare. Setup the environment to do the job. Consider ways to make setup less difficult.
- Confirm. Once preparation is complete, what does the customer need to verify before proceeding with the job to ensure its successful execution?
- Execute. Provide customers with real-time feedback or automatically correct execution problems.
- Monitor. Assess whether the job is being successfully executed. Link monitoring with improved execution.
- Modify. Make alterations to improve execution. Reduce the need to make alterations and the number needed.
- Conclude. Finish the job or prepare to repeat it. Simplify the process of completing the job.
 
b.) List Desired Outcomes under each (based on assumptions and understanding of domain to start, then fill out with research).
 

- Desired outcomes typically state a direction of improvement (minimize or increase); contain a unit of measure (number, time, frequency, likelihood); and state what outcome is desired.
- In most cases a dozen or so outcomes define success at each step.

## Survey Outcomes

Survey Outcomes and prioritize based on results. (Which are important? Which are underserved by the market? Which are underperforming?)
 
1. Prepare a survey instrument (questionnaire) that states all the job, outcome, and constraint statements that have been captured from customer interviews and from screening and profiling questions. 
1. Administer the survey to a statistically valid representation of the target population (often between 180 and 600 people). 
1. Ask the survey participants to rate the importance of all the jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means critically important and 1 means not important at all. 
1. Ask the survey participants the degree to which they are satisfied with how the solutions they are using today address those jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means totally satisfied and 1 means not satisfied at all. 
1. Enter the results into the opportunity algorithm to determine which jobs, outcomes, and constraints are underserved and overserved. Algorithm: Importance + max (Importance-Satisfaction,0) = Opportunity

🛠 To facilitate this for in-person interviews, I use the Custom Fields Power Up and add a number field named “Votes” and increment for each time a desired outcome is brought up.
 
## How Might We?

Choose areas and start with _How Might We_ questions, to ideate.
 
🛠 Trello card descriptions; or move to spreadsheet/Sketch to add other dimensions to map out the journey (e.g., emotion, context, etc.).
 
 The resulting structure looks something like this:
 
- JTBD
    - Job Step
        - Desired Outcomes
            - HMW
        - Other dimensions (e.g., emotion, context, metrics, channels, touchpoints, timeline)

# References

- Paul’s Notes on What Customers Want
- http://strategyn.com/2013/10/14/tony-ulwick-presents-at-openco/
- https://chrisgurney.ca/images/portfolio-fuzzies/journey-full.pdf

Example from _What Customers Want_:
 
> The interviewers focused the discussion on the activities associated with setting up and managing an insured’s account. They asked the agents what they were trying to achieve when obtaining quotes, preparing agreements, obtaining approvals, managing late paying accounts, posting payments, and reinstating policies. To obtain the agents’ desired outcomes, the interviewers instructed them to think through each of these activities during a typical day as they obtained quotes and offerings from different insurance companies. The interviewers asked the agents, “What makes one insurance company’s offering better or worse than another, and why? And what characteristics describe the ideal service offering?” By forcing this type of discussion, the interviewers were able to prompt the agents to reveal their desired outcomes.

> They might say, “I do not like it when I have to spend half a day reinstating a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer because they mailed the bill to the wrong address.” Upon hearing this statement an interviewer might say, “So this situation could be improved if you were able to minimize the time it takes to reinstate a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer.” The agent might say, “Exactly”—in which case, the statement would be accepted as an outcome—or “No, I just wish the insurer would stop inadvertently canceling policies.” In this case, the interviewer would say, “So you want to minimize the likelihood that a policy is inadvertently canceled by the insurer,” and validate that the statement is correct.

card.name: Design Principles
card.desc:
Core design principles that apply to everything:

- Simplicity
- Reflect/Reuse Existing Patterns
- Discoverability
- Offer Forgiveness
- Provide Feedback


![Neighbor logo](images/design-process/svg/logo-neighbor.svg)

For example, my designs for [Neighbor](neighbor-brand.html)'s UI followed these principles:

- _Findability._ Provide answers to customers on the phone, and make updates quickly. Scanability, search.
- _Performance._ Fast.
- _For humans._ Simple language. No manuals. Flexible workflows.
- _Intentional changes._

card.name: Design Stories
card.desc:
# FORMAT

Goal(s)
Job Stories (which become sub-tasks)
Out of Scope
Deliverables
[Other Design Requirements]


# EXAMPLE 1

**Goal(s)**

Continue research into needs for portal and wireframe screens.

Start with use cases for:

- Login
- Password Recovery
- Employee Activation Flow
- Customer Add/Edit
- Employee Profile
- Employee Add/Edit
- 1-2 others based on scope from PM?

**Job Stories**

1. [Employee] When I want to [add a customer / run a report / make an update / etc.], I want to log into the system quickly, so that I can perform the task at hand.
1. [Employee] When I can’t remember my password, I want to reset it easily, so I can get back into the system to perform my job.
1. [Employee] When I’ve been invited to sign up for an account, I want to be able to provide my information, so that I can start using the system to perform my job (e.g., start supporting customers).
1. [Employee] When I want to update [my password / name / etc.], I want to be able to easily update my profile, so that my record is up to date.
1. [Support] When I have a new Customer on the phone, I want to add them to the system quickly, so that we can start the provisioning process (i.e., get them energy, or the service) as soon as possible (to recognize revenue).
1. [Support] When I want to update an existing Customer’s information (e.g., they moved), I want to update their record easily, so that their information will be up to date (i.e., they’re properly billed / they get future bills in the mail / etc.).
1. [Admin] When I have a new Employee who needs access to the system, I want to be able to add them easily, so I can get them using the system right away.
1. [Admin] When I want to update an existing Employee’s information (e.g., role), I want to update their record quickly, so I can support them in doing their their job.

**Out of Scope**

Mobile screen sizes. To be researched.

**Deliverables**

Wireframes from Sketch, prototyped in InVision.

Tasks and corresponding usability test feedback from at least 5 testers.



# Example 2

**Goal**

We’ll need branded emails in order to communicate to customers from the system, including sending bills to customers.

**Job Stories**

1. [Customer] When a bill has been created, I want to receive it in my inbox, so that I can review it.
1. [Customer] When an account is created for me, I want to receive a welcome email, so that I know that I what future emails to expect.
1. [Customer] When I make a purchase (via a CSR), I want to receive an email letting me know what I purchased, so that I can feel confident the changes I wanted will be made, and so that I know its impact on my next bill.

**Design Requirements**

Emails must be brand-able (via logo and colors only).

Emails must be responsive.

**Deliverables**

Responsive HTML and images for above emails.

Source delivered to dev to GTBilling repo (if possible) and https://bitbucket.org/globalivetechnology/email/src/master/

Images deployed to S3 bucket (for Billing project), if setup in time; otherwise some other public URL for testing.

card.name: Jobs to Be Done
card.desc:
(Ulwick)

→ Survey for existing features

(Summarize the Following)


# The JTBD Approach
 
## Identify what job the customer is trying to get done.
 
- Expressed as a Job Story:
    - When…(situation) I want… (motivation) so that… (expected outcome).
- We think about the job from the customer’s perspective, not the company’s. 
- We think big; to encompass the entire job, not just a piece of it.
- Functional jobs define the tasks people seek to accomplish, personal jobs explain the way people want to feel in a given circumstance, and social jobs clarify how people want to be perceived by others.

🛠 Tooling: I use an empty Trello board. Starting from the left: 

- "TO FILE" - For all the ideas that arise during this process, without worrying where to put them right away.
- “JTBD" - For the job itself. I also attach a sketch of the flow here.
- Following that, each column represents each process step (“Discovery”, “Sign Up”, etc.). Use the Universal Job Map (below) if needed to determine ideas for each column.

 
## For each Job
 
a.) Determine stages (process steps) for the job. Can be based on the Universal Job Map (if helpful as a starting point):
 
- Define. Customers determine their goals and plan resources. Simplify planning.
- Locate. Customers gather items and information necessary to do the job.
- Prepare. Setup the environment to do the job. Consider ways to make setup less difficult.
- Confirm. Once preparation is complete, what does the customer need to verify before proceeding with the job to ensure its successful execution?
- Execute. Provide customers with real-time feedback or automatically correct execution problems.
- Monitor. Assess whether the job is being successfully executed. Link monitoring with improved execution.
- Modify. Make alterations to improve execution. Reduce the need to make alterations and the number needed.
- Conclude. Finish the job or prepare to repeat it. Simplify the process of completing the job.
 
b.) List Desired Outcomes under each (based on assumptions and understanding of domain to start, then fill out with research).
 

- Desired outcomes typically state a direction of improvement (minimize or increase); contain a unit of measure (number, time, frequency, likelihood); and state what outcome is desired.
- In most cases a dozen or so outcomes define success at each step.

## Survey Outcomes

Survey Outcomes and prioritize based on results. (Which are important? Which are underserved by the market? Which are underperforming?)
 
1. Prepare a survey instrument (questionnaire) that states all the job, outcome, and constraint statements that have been captured from customer interviews and from screening and profiling questions. 
1. Administer the survey to a statistically valid representation of the target population (often between 180 and 600 people). 
1. Ask the survey participants to rate the importance of all the jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means critically important and 1 means not important at all. 
1. Ask the survey participants the degree to which they are satisfied with how the solutions they are using today address those jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means totally satisfied and 1 means not satisfied at all. 
1. Enter the results into the opportunity algorithm to determine which jobs, outcomes, and constraints are underserved and overserved. Algorithm: Importance + max (Importance-Satisfaction,0) = Opportunity

🛠 To facilitate this for in-person interviews, I use the Custom Fields Power Up and add a number field named “Votes” and increment for each time a desired outcome is brought up.
 
## How Might We?

Choose areas and start with _How Might We_ questions, to ideate.
 
🛠 Trello card descriptions; or move to spreadsheet/Sketch to add other dimensions to map out the journey (e.g., emotion, context, etc.).
 
 The resulting structure looks something like this:
 
- JTBD
    - Job Step
        - Desired Outcomes
            - HMW
        - Other dimensions (e.g., emotion, context, metrics, channels, touchpoints, timeline)
 

# REFERENCES
 
- Paul’s Notes on What Customers Want
- http://strategyn.com/2013/10/14/tony-ulwick-presents-at-openco/
- https://chrisgurney.ca/images/portfolio-fuzzies/journey-full.pdf

# EXAMPLES
 
From _What Customers Want_:
 
- The interviewers focused the discussion on the activities associated with setting up and managing an insured’s account. They asked the agents what they were trying to achieve when obtaining quotes, preparing agreements, obtaining approvals, managing late paying accounts, posting payments, and reinstating policies. To obtain the agents’ desired outcomes, the interviewers instructed them to think through each of these activities during a typical day as they obtained quotes and offerings from different insurance companies. The interviewers asked the agents, “What makes one insurance company’s offering better or worse than another, and why? And what characteristics describe the ideal service offering?” By forcing this type of discussion, the interviewers were able to prompt the agents to reveal their desired outcomes.
- They might say, “I do not like it when I have to spend half a day reinstating a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer because they mailed the bill to the wrong address.” Upon hearing this statement an interviewer might say, “So this situation could be improved if you were able to minimize the time it takes to reinstate a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer.” The agent might say, “Exactly”—in which case, the statement would be accepted as an outcome—or “No, I just wish the insurer would stop inadvertently canceling policies.” In this case, the interviewer would say, “So you want to minimize the likelihood that a policy is inadvertently canceled by the insurer,” and validate that the statement is correct.

card.name: Agile
card.desc:
Agile is a conversation.

Be involved in backlog grooming, retrospectives, and other regular Agile activities.

I prefer to do my design work in one week sprints, to keep myself track on constantly producing deliverables.

I recommend managing Design Team work in a separate JIRA project, separate from the Development Team's sprints, so that: Development can commit to, and completely finish their work for a given sprint; and Design's workflow can be customized and separate from Development's.

The workflow can be as simple as:

- Backlog
- In Progress
- Review - Present to and discuss with stakeholders.
- Done - Ready for implementation.

[kanban board columns: Backlog, In Progress, Review, Done]

🛠 **Tools**: Trello, JIRA, Spreadsheets

card.name: Research Plan (+ hypothesis questions to ask)

cards.desc:
Before getting started, my first step is to understand the context that I as a Designer am operating within.

Key Questions:

- What is the project's scope?
- What are the business's, project's, and technical constraints?
- Who are the stakeholders? 
- How can I integrate into the Development team's process?
- What are the assumptions we're operating under?
- What are the risks?
- What is the company's UX process and how mature is it?

cards.name: Journey Map

cards.desc:
(Ulwick)

→ Survey for existing features
→ Job Map

(Summarize the Following)


# My JTBD Approach

## Identify what job the customer is trying to get done.
 
- Expressed as a Job Story:
    - When…(situation) I want… (motivation) so that… (expected outcome).
- We think about the job from the customer’s perspective, not the company’s. 
- We think big; to encompass the entire job, not just a piece of it.
- Functional jobs define the tasks people seek to accomplish, personal jobs explain the way people want to feel in a given circumstance, and social jobs clarify how people want to be perceived by others.

🛠 Tooling: I use an empty Trello board. Starting from the left: 

- "TO FILE" - For all the ideas that arise during this process, without worrying where to put them right away.
- “JTBD" - For the job itself. I also attach a sketch of the flow here.
- Following that, each column represents each process step (“Discovery”, “Sign Up”, etc.). Use the Universal Job Map (below) if needed to determine ideas for each column.

## For each Job...

a.) Determine stages (process steps) for the job. Can be based on the Universal Job Map (if helpful as a starting point):
 
- Define. Customers determine their goals and plan resources. Simplify planning.
- Locate. Customers gather items and information necessary to do the job.
- Prepare. Setup the environment to do the job. Consider ways to make setup less difficult.
- Confirm. Once preparation is complete, what does the customer need to verify before proceeding with the job to ensure its successful execution?
- Execute. Provide customers with real-time feedback or automatically correct execution problems.
- Monitor. Assess whether the job is being successfully executed. Link monitoring with improved execution.
- Modify. Make alterations to improve execution. Reduce the need to make alterations and the number needed.
- Conclude. Finish the job or prepare to repeat it. Simplify the process of completing the job.
 
b.) List Desired Outcomes under each (based on assumptions and understanding of domain to start, then fill out with research).
 

- Desired outcomes typically state a direction of improvement (minimize or increase); contain a unit of measure (number, time, frequency, likelihood); and state what outcome is desired.
- In most cases a dozen or so outcomes define success at each step.

## Survey Outcomes

Survey Outcomes and prioritize based on results. (Which are important? Which are underserved by the market? Which are underperforming?)
 
1. Prepare a survey instrument (questionnaire) that states all the job, outcome, and constraint statements that have been captured from customer interviews and from screening and profiling questions. 
1. Administer the survey to a statistically valid representation of the target population (often between 180 and 600 people). 
1. Ask the survey participants to rate the importance of all the jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means critically important and 1 means not important at all. 
1. Ask the survey participants the degree to which they are satisfied with how the solutions they are using today address those jobs, outcomes, and constraints using a scale of 1 to 5, where 5 means totally satisfied and 1 means not satisfied at all. 
1. Enter the results into the opportunity algorithm to determine which jobs, outcomes, and constraints are underserved and overserved. Algorithm: Importance + max (Importance-Satisfaction,0) = Opportunity

🛠 To facilitate this for in-person interviews, I use the Custom Fields Power Up and add a number field named “Votes” and increment for each time a desired outcome is brought up.
 
## How Might We?

Choose areas and start with _How Might We_ questions, to ideate.
 
🛠 Trello card descriptions; or move to spreadsheet/Sketch to add other dimensions to map out the journey (e.g., emotion, context, etc.).
 
 The resulting structure looks something like this:
 
- JTBD
    - Job Step
        - Desired Outcomes
            - HMW
        - Other dimensions (e.g., emotion, context, metrics, channels, touchpoints, timeline)

# References

- Paul’s Notes on What Customers Want
- http://strategyn.com/2013/10/14/tony-ulwick-presents-at-openco/
- https://chrisgurney.ca/images/portfolio-fuzzies/journey-full.pdf

Example from _What Customers Want_:
 
> The interviewers focused the discussion on the activities associated with setting up and managing an insured’s account. They asked the agents what they were trying to achieve when obtaining quotes, preparing agreements, obtaining approvals, managing late paying accounts, posting payments, and reinstating policies. To obtain the agents’ desired outcomes, the interviewers instructed them to think through each of these activities during a typical day as they obtained quotes and offerings from different insurance companies. The interviewers asked the agents, “What makes one insurance company’s offering better or worse than another, and why? And what characteristics describe the ideal service offering?” By forcing this type of discussion, the interviewers were able to prompt the agents to reveal their desired outcomes.

> They might say, “I do not like it when I have to spend half a day reinstating a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer because they mailed the bill to the wrong address.” Upon hearing this statement an interviewer might say, “So this situation could be improved if you were able to minimize the time it takes to reinstate a policy that was inadvertently canceled by the insurer.” The agent might say, “Exactly”—in which case, the statement would be accepted as an outcome—or “No, I just wish the insurer would stop inadvertently canceling policies.” In this case, the interviewer would say, “So you want to minimize the likelihood that a policy is inadvertently canceled by the insurer,” and validate that the statement is correct.
cards.name: Jobs To Be Done

cards.desc:
# FORMAT

Goal(s)
Job Stories (which become sub-tasks)
Out of Scope
Deliverables
[Other Design Requirements]


# EXAMPLE 1

**Goal(s)**

Continue research into needs for portal and wireframe screens.

Start with use cases for:

- Login
- Password Recovery
- Employee Activation Flow
- Customer Add/Edit
- Employee Profile
- Employee Add/Edit
- 1-2 others based on scope from PM?

**Job Stories**

1. [Employee] When I want to [add a customer / run a report / make an update / etc.], I want to log into the system quickly, so that I can perform the task at hand.
1. [Employee] When I can’t remember my password, I want to reset it easily, so I can get back into the system to perform my job.
1. [Employee] When I’ve been invited to sign up for an account, I want to be able to provide my information, so that I can start using the system to perform my job (e.g., start supporting customers).
1. [Employee] When I want to update [my password / name / etc.], I want to be able to easily update my profile, so that my record is up to date.
1. [Support] When I have a new Customer on the phone, I want to add them to the system quickly, so that we can start the provisioning process (i.e., get them energy, or the service) as soon as possible (to recognize revenue).
1. [Support] When I want to update an existing Customer’s information (e.g., they moved), I want to update their record easily, so that their information will be up to date (i.e., they’re properly billed / they get future bills in the mail / etc.).
1. [Admin] When I have a new Employee who needs access to the system, I want to be able to add them easily, so I can get them using the system right away.
1. [Admin] When I want to update an existing Employee’s information (e.g., role), I want to update their record quickly, so I can support them in doing their their job.

**Out of Scope**

Mobile screen sizes. To be researched.

**Deliverables**

Wireframes from Sketch, prototyped in InVision.

Tasks and corresponding usability test feedback from at least 5 testers.



# Example 2

**Goal**

We’ll need branded emails in order to communicate to customers from the system, including sending bills to customers.

**Job Stories**

1. [Customer] When a bill has been created, I want to receive it in my inbox, so that I can review it.
1. [Customer] When an account is created for me, I want to receive a welcome email, so that I know that I what future emails to expect.
1. [Customer] When I make a purchase (via a CSR), I want to receive an email letting me know what I purchased, so that I can feel confident the changes I wanted will be made, and so that I know its impact on my next bill.

**Design Requirements**

Emails must be brand-able (via logo and colors only).

Emails must be responsive.

**Deliverables**

Responsive HTML and images for above emails.

Source delivered to dev to GTBilling repo (if possible).

Images deployed to S3 bucket (for Billing project), if setup in time; otherwise some other public URL for testing.

cards.desc:
Core design principles that apply to everything:

- Simplicity
- Reflect/Reuse Existing Patterns
- Discoverability
- Offer Forgiveness
- Provide Feedback


![Neighbor logo](images/design-process/svg/logo-neighbor.svg)

For example, my designs for [Neighbor](neighbor-brand.html)'s UI followed these principles:

- _Findability._ Provide answers to customers on the phone, and make updates quickly. Scanability, search.
- _Performance._ Fast.
- _For humans._ Simple language. No manuals. Flexible workflows.
- _Intentional changes._
